OngoingResearchSupport.description: Multi-modal insights of spatially distributed cells with associations of diseases and drug response. Aim: The overall goals are to develop a novel class of machine learning, statistical and deep learning approaches for the enhancement, prioritization, and interpretation of spatially organized cells in complex tissue, through leveraging resources including GWAS studies and pharmacogenomics knowledgebase, thus to better understand the molecular mechanisms underpinning disease and drug response.

University of Florida Health Cancer Center Support Grant. Aim: The new UFHCC strategic plan, Momentum 2027, has 4 pillars: 1) conduct transdisciplinary research (RNA biology, microbiome); 2) translate UFHCC discoveries to trials (immunotherapy, small molecules, cancer communication); 3) address cancer burden (cancer and aging, cancer health disparities); and, 4) train a prepared and diverse cancer research workforce, including leadership development. UFHCC is poised to make a major impact on the cancer burden of the catchment area, Florida, and beyond.

Predicative Modeling of the Prevalence of Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer Biomarkers. Aim: We aim to assess the association of HER2 status with multiple demographic, behavioral, and clinical characteristics in geographically different and diverse populations within the United States. We will develop and validate the model using institutional electronic health records data from three cancer centers. We will then apply the prediction model to national cancer registry data to estimate the prevalence of HER2 status in NSCLC patients.

A germline- and promoter-independent strategy to gain access to all cell types in the brain. Aim: We propose to develop an AAV-based Cell-Type-Specific Targeting (ACTSTar) system to enable easy access to any cell type in the brain in any species that is independent of germline modification and promoter isolation and characterization. We plan to generate a library of ACTSTar drivers to target 50 different brain cell types in the mouse and marmoset. In addition, to reduce off-target integration and neuroinflammation associated with long-term Cas9 expression, especially in long-term experiments in primates.

Pending.description: Multi-Modal AI Model for Enhancing Drug Screening in Peripheral Arterial Disease. Goal: The primary goal of this project is to revolutionize drug screening and therapeutic development for Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD) by developing and integrating advanced multi-modal artificial intelligence (AI) technologies. This will involve combining spatial transcriptomics, pathology images, and a comprehensive knowledge graph with AI-driven approaches to better understand the PAD microenvironment and improve treatment options.

Multi-organ and Multi-scale Computational Modeling of Alzheimer's Disease. Goal: This project seeks to advance our understanding of the genetic links between cardiovascular and neurological phenotypes, enhancing AD diagnosis and facilitating the development of personalized therapeutic strategies.

Live longer, live healthier: graph causal artificial intelligence for precision immunotherapy. Aim: Our multidisciplinary research team proposes to use a causal artificial intelligence model, gCAI, to reliably estimate the individual renal toxicity difference (ΔIRT) among candidate drugs as well as the individual treatment effects (ITE) for cancer patients. Such counterfactual prediction models will provide actionable knowledge of which treatments are safe and effective for a specific patient.

Completed.description: Targeted Anchoring Ecto-enzyme on Cancer Cell Surface to Enhance Antibody Therapy in Breast Cancer. Goal: We will elucidate the mechanisms of TME reprograming by surface ADA anchoring and will develop an approach to enhance surface ADA anchoring by combination with a tyrosine kinase inhibitor. This project can be directly translated into a targeted cancer immunotherapy to treat patients with HER2+ BC. By addressing lack of disease specificity, a main obstacle to the development of next-generation immunotherapeutic regimens, we will contribute to the use of precision medicine for cancer immunotherapy.

Establishing the Repertoire of Actionable Alterations in Appendiceal Adenocarcinoma. Overall goal: To develop a working knowledge base of the genetic alterations that underlie appendiceal adenocarcinoma (AA) and pursue development of actionable genetic tests to guide critical AA treatment decisions. My responsibility is to assist biologists to identify the genetic alterations in AA patients and related single-cell analysis.

Dissecting functions of IL-23-dependent inflammatory Th17 cells. Goal: We propose to identify the mechanisms by which a metabolomic enzyme is selectively required for Th17-mediated autoimmunity but not Th17-dependent defensive immunity.
